homes_hear_details: Missouri's HOMES and HEAR programs are pending launch. The Missouri Department of Natural Resources - Division of Energy is developing implementation plans using approximately $77 million in IRA funding allocated to the state.
state_energy_office: Missouri Department of Natural Resources - Division of Energy

income_thresholds.low_income_80_ami: For a family of four in St. Louis, 80% AMI is approximately $61,600. For Kansas City, 80% AMI is approximately $62,000. Low-income households will qualify for the highest rebate levels under HOMES when launched.
income_thresholds.moderate_income_150_ami: For a family of four in St. Louis, 150% AMI is approximately $115,500. For Kansas City, 150% AMI is approximately $116,250. Moderate-income households will qualify for partial rebates under HOMES when launched.

net_metering: Missouri's net metering law allows systems up to 100 kW for residential customers. Excess generation is credited at the retail rate. Monthly excess credits roll over, and annual surplus is purchased by the utility at the avoided cost rate. The Missouri Public Service Commission oversees net metering for investor-owned utilities.

state_tax_credits.name: Missouri does not currently offer state-level tax credits for residential renewable energy
state_tax_credits.details: Missouri does not have state solar tax credits or energy efficiency tax credits. However, Missouri does have a property tax exemption for solar energy systems under the Missouri Solar Property Tax Exemption, which excludes the added value of solar from property tax assessments. Residents can claim the federal 30% ITC.
